text.text_translated:
'The Hunger Games' is the name of a book.  
Suzanne Collins wrote it.  
One night in 2003, she was flipping between channels on TV.  
It was during the US invasion of Iraq.  
She saw only two kinds of TV shows.  
One kind had young people trying to win a million dollars.  
The other kind had news about the war.  
She saw the two things mix in a disturbing way.  
Then she got the idea for 'The Hunger Games'.

feedback.feedback: FAIL: Fidelity Failure. The BERTScore of 0.898 is below the required 0.90. The phrase reality programmes was replaced by two kinds of TV shows, reducing key lexical overlap. Suggestion: restore the term reality programmes and maintain the original phrase competing to win a million dollars to improve fidelity.

best_attempt.text_translated:
'The Hunger Games' is a book.  
Suzanne Collins wrote it.  
One night in 2003 she flipped between TV channels.  
It was the time of the US invasion of Iraq.  
The only programmes she could find on TV were two kinds.  
One kind was competition shows.  
Young people competed to win one million dollars.  
The other kind was news about the war in Iraq.  
The two things start to merge together in a bad way.  
Then the idea for 'The Hunger Games' came to her.
